elements.content: We have synthesized the HC^Npz ligand, 1-(naphthalen-2-yl)-1H-pyrazole (1A), and carried out its cyclometalation reaction with [{Pt­(η3-C4H7)­(μ-Cl)}2] to give [{Pt­(Naph^N)­(μ-Cl)}2]. This process takes place via the intermediate [Pt­(η3-C4H7)­Cl­(HNaph^N-κN)] (2A) which could be isolated and fully characterized. Compound [{Pt­(Naph^N)­(μ-Cl)}2] and the analogous N-heterocyclic carbene complex [{Pt­(Naph^C*)­(μ-Cl)}2] (HNaph^C*-κC* = 3-methyl-1-(naphthalen-2-yl)-1H-imidazol-2-ylidene) were used to prepare the bis-cyanide anionic derivatives N n Bu4­[Pt­(Naph^E)­(CN)2] (E = Npz 4A, C*carbene 4B) which subsequently react with TlPF6 to afford the corresponding complexes [PtTl­(Naph^E)­(CN)2] (5A and 5B). The X-ray structures of 5A and 5B show the presence of 2D extended networks created by organometallic “PtTl­(Naph^E)­(CN)2” entities, each one containing a Pt→Tl dative bond (d Pt–Tl = 3.0205(3) Å 5A, 2.9395(4) Å 5B). These units are linked together through additional Tl···​NC and Tl···π contacts, which, in the case of 5B, renders a stair-like arrangement. NBO charge distributions analysis on 4A and 4B shows a small negative charge on the Pt center for 4B, while positive for 4A, indicating the more electron donating character of the carbene with respect to the pyrazole group. 195Pt and 13C NMR spectra of N n Bu4­[Pt­(Naph^E)­(13CN)2] (E = Npz 4A′, C*carbene 4B′) account for this difference. Photophysical analysis has been performed for 4A/B and 5A/B regarding the Naph^E fragment. The emissions of 4A and 4B in CH2Cl2 at 77 K present similar profiles and have been assigned to 3ILCT [π­(Naph^E) → π*­(Naph^E)] excited states. The green emission of 4A in poly­(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) film (5 wt %) affords a photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY, Φ) of 82%. In the solid state, the vibronic emissions of 5A (λmax = 528 nm) and 5B (λmax = 561 nm) are red-shifted in relation to their precursors (λmax = 488 nm 4A, 530 nm 4B) and are mainly attributed to 3MM′LCT [d/s σ*­(Pt,Tl) → π*­(Naph^E)] excited states.

This process takes place via the intermediate [Pt(η3-C4H7)Cl(HNaph^N-κN)] (2A) which could be isolated and fully characterized. Compound [{Pt(Naph^N)(μ-Cl)}2] and the analogous N-heterocyclic carbene complex [{Pt(Naph^C*)(μ-Cl)}2] (HNaph^C*-κC* = 3-methyl-1-(naphthalen-2-yl)-1H-imidazol-2-ylidene) were used to prepare the bis-cyanide anionic derivatives N n Bu4[Pt(Naph^E)(CN)2] (E = Npz 4A, C*carbene 4B) which subsequently react with TlPF6 to afford the corresponding complexes [PtTl(Naph^E)(CN)2] (5A and 5B). The X-ray structures of 5A and 5B show the presence of 2D extended networks created by organometallic "PtTl(Naph^E)(CN)2" entities, each one containing a Pt→Tl dative bond (d Pt-Tl = 3.0205(3) Å 5A, 2.9395(4) Å 5B). These units are linked together through additional Tl⋅⋅⋅NC and Tl⋅⋅⋅π contacts, which, in the case of 5B, renders a stair-like arrangement. NBO charge distributions analysis on 4A and 4B shows a small negative charge on the Pt center for 4B, while positive for 4A, indicating the more electron donating character of the carbene with respect to the pyrazole group. 195Pt and 13C NMR spectra of N n Bu4[Pt(Naph^E)(13CN)2] (E = Npz 4A', C*carbene 4B') account for this difference. The emissions of 4A and 4B in CH2Cl2 at 77 K present similar profiles and have been assigned to 3ILCT [π(Naph^E) → π*(Naph^E)] excited states. In the solid state, the vibronic emissions of 5A (λmax = 528 nm) and 5B (λmax = 561 nm) are red-shifted in relation to their precursors (λmax = 488 nm 4A, 530 nm 4B) and are mainly attributed to 3MM'LCT [d/s σ*(Pt,Tl) → π*(Naph^E)] excited states.

elements.content: Phosphorescent square-planar platinum complexes are an active research area in the fields of biological labeling, chemical sensing, and light emitting devices. The emissive behavior of these compounds can arise from discrete molecular species, by introducing strong field ligands that raise the energy level of the radiationless d–d states and increase the quantum efficiency. To achieve this, the cyclometalated aryl-pyridine ligands are well-suited systems due to their electronic features derived from the σ–donor (aryl) and π–acceptor (imine) fragments. Besides, they present synthetically accessible modification sites within the cyclometalating skeleton that consequently vary the emitting light color across the visible spectrum. Likewise, the monodentate ancillary ligands L play an important role in the spectral tuning of emitted light and also in the solid-state aggregation and intermolecular interactions. In this regard, when using nonbulky ligands, the square-planar complexes can interact with each other through π–π or Pt–Pt stacking interactions which can give rise to different species of higher nuclearity (excimers or aggregates). Consequently, a change in the nature of the emissive states is produced; therefore, the 3ππ* or 3MMLCT excited states lead to phosphorescent red-shifted emissions in relation to those of the discrete monomer, which originated from 3IL/3MLCT states.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Phosphorescent square-planar platinum complexes are an active research area in the fields of biological labeling, chemical sensing, and light emitting devices. The emissive behavior of these compounds can arise from discrete molecular species, by introducing strong field ligands that raise the energy level of the radiationless d-d states and increase the quantum efficiency. To achieve this, the cyclometalated aryl-pyridine ligands are well-suited systems due to their electronic features derived from the σ-donor (aryl) and π-acceptor (imine) fragments. Besides, they present synthetically accessible modification sites within the cyclometalating skeleton that consequently vary the emitting light color across the visible spectrum. Likewise, the monodentate ancillary ligands L play an important role in the spectral tuning of emitted light and also in the solid-state aggregation and intermolecular interactions. In this regard, when using nonbulky ligands, the square-planar complexes can interact with each other through π-π or Pt-Pt stacking interactions which can give rise to different species of higher nuclearity (excimers or aggregates). Consequently, a change in the nature of the emissive states is produced; therefore, the 3ππ* or 3MMLCT excited states lead to phosphorescent red-shifted emissions in relation to those of the discrete monomer, which originated from 3IL/3MLCT states.

elements.content: Many square-planar Pt­(II) compounds have been proved to behave as Lewis bases to give Metal Only Lewis Pairs (MOLP) complexes featuring Pt­(II)→M (M = Cu­(I), Ag­(I), Au­(I), Cd­(II), Hg­(II), Tl­(I), Pb­(II)) dative bonds. These metal–metal interactions observed in heterometallic systems have been utilized as well as a powerful tool to tune the properties of complexes by the simple modulation of distances and orientations between the units. Among the heterometallic complexes, those containing PtII–TlI dative metal–metal linkages are versatile systems to create extended structures with functional properties such as photoluminescence ([{Pt­(R-C^C*)­(acac)}2Tl]­PF6, [TlPt­(C4H9N4)­(CN)2], “Tl2Pt­(C6F5)2­(CN)2”, [TlPt­(C^N)­(CN)2],), vapochromism ([{Pt­(bzq)­(C6F5)2}­Tl­(Me2CO)] n ), or mechanochromism ([{Pt­(C6F5)­(C^N)}­Tl­(SpyCF3-5)] n ). In this area, we have reported the use of anionic bis-cyanide complexes N n Bu4­[M­(C^N)­(CN)2] (M = Pd, Pt) with 7,8-benzoquinolinato (bzq) and 2-phenylpyridinato (ppy) as C^N cyclometalated ligands to create 2D-extended structures with donor–acceptor M→Tl bonds (M = Pd, Pt). Due to the presence of M–Tl bonds and the secondary interactions within the assembled network, the yellow emissions of the corresponding precursors, typically originating from 3ILCT/3MLCT excited states, are fairly modified and shifted to the red spectral region.
elements.clean_text: Many square-planar Pt(II) compounds have been proved to behave as Lewis bases to give Metal Only Lewis Pairs (MOLP) complexes featuring Pt(II)→M (M = Cu(I), Ag(I), Au(I), Cd(II), Hg(II), Tl(I), Pb(II)) dative bonds. These metal-metal interactions observed in heterometallic systems have been utilized as well as a powerful tool to tune the properties of complexes by the simple modulation of distances and orientations between the units. Among the heterometallic complexes, those containing PtII-TlI dative metal-metal linkages are versatile systems to create extended structures with functional properties such as photoluminescence ([{Pt(R-C^C*)(acac)}2Tl]PF6, [TlPt(C4H9N4)(CN)2], "Tl2Pt(C6F5)2(CN)2", [TlPt(C^N)(CN)2],), vapochromism ([{Pt(bzq)(C6F5)2}Tl(Me2CO)] n  ), or mechanochromism ([{Pt(C6F5)(C^N)}Tl(SpyCF3-5)] n  ). In this area, we have reported the use of anionic bis-cyanide complexes N n Bu4[M(C^N)(CN)2] (M = Pd, Pt) with 7,8-benzoquinolinato (bzq) and 2-phenylpyridinato (ppy) as C^N cyclometalated ligands to create 2D-extended structures with donor-acceptor M→Tl bonds (M = Pd, Pt). Due to the presence of M-Tl bonds and the secondary interactions within the assembled network, the yellow emissions of the corresponding precursors, typically originating from 3ILCT/3MLCT excited states, are fairly modified and shifted to the red spectral region.

elements.content: Having in mind that C,N-cyclometalated compounds with a poor π-acceptor neutral fragment like pyrazole instead of a pyridine would enlarge the energy gap and alter the emissive properties and that the aryl-pyrazole platinum compounds have been barely explored, we decided to expand the investigation to a new synthon N n Bu4[Pt­(C^N)­(CN)2] (HC^N = 1-(naphthalen-2-yl)-1H-pyrazole, 4A) whose cyclometalated skeleton (Pt­(Naph^N)) also presents structural similarities with the N-heterocyclic carbene species (Pt­(Naph^C*)) we have recently been investigating on. Thus, compound N n Bu4­[Pt­(Naph^N)­(CN)2] (4A) and the counterpart, N n Bu4­[Pt­(Naph^C*)­(CN)2] (HC^C*-κC* = 3-methyl-1-(naphthalen-2-yl)-1H-imidazol-2-ylidene, 4B), recently published by Kato and co-workers, have been reacted with TlPF6 to afford neutral extended structures containing Pt–Tl dative bonds, [PtTl­(Naph^E)­(CN)2] (E = pyrazole 5A, carbene 5B). Structural and photophysical comparative analyses have been performed regarding the cyclometalated Pt­(Naph^E) motif.

Thus, compound N n Bu4[Pt(Naph^N)(CN)2] (4A) and the counterpart, N n Bu4[Pt(Naph^C*)(CN)2] (HC^C*-κC* = 3-methyl-1-(naphthalen-2-yl)-1H-imidazol-2-ylidene, 4B), recently published by Kato and co-workers, have been reacted with TlPF6 to afford neutral extended structures containing Pt-Tl dative bonds, [PtTl(Naph^E)(CN)2] (E = pyrazole 5A, carbene 5B). Structural and photophysical comparative analyses have been performed regarding the cyclometalated Pt(Naph^E) motif.

elements.content: The synthesis of the 1-(naphthalen-2-yl)-1H-pyrazole (HNaph^N 1A) was accomplished by a modified Ullmann-type condensation (, step a, and Figure S1). 2-Bromonaphthalene was coupled with pyrazole in DMSO at 130 °C using copper­(I) oxide and potassium carbonate. After workup, 1A was obtained by precipitation with n-hexane in good yield (ca. 76%). Keeping on with our developed protocol to prepare C^N- and C^C*-cyclometalated complexes of platinum­(II), the HNaph^N ligand was reacted with the dichlorido-bridged complex [{Pt­(η3-C4H7)­(μ-Cl)}2] (Z) (η3-C4H7 = η3-2-methylallyl) in CH2Cl2 to yield compound 2A (see , step b, and for details) as a pure, air-stable solid.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Preparation of the HNaph^N Ligand. One Pot and Stepwise Strategies for Cyclometalation to Pt(II)

The synthesis of the 1-(naphthalen-2-yl)-1H-pyrazole (HNaph^N 1A) was accomplished by a modified Ullmann-type condensation (, step a, and Figure S1). 2-Bromonaphthalene was coupled with pyrazole in DMSO at 130 °C using copper(I) oxide and potassium carbonate. After workup, 1A was obtained by precipitation with n-hexane in good yield (ca. 76%). Keeping on with our developed protocol to prepare C^N- and C^C*-cyclometalated complexes of platinum(II), the HNaph^N ligand was reacted with the dichlorido-bridged complex [{Pt(η3-C4H7)(μ-Cl)}2] (Z) (η3-C4H7 = η3-2-methylallyl) in CH2Cl2 to yield compound 2A (see , step b, and  for details) as a pure, air-stable solid.

elements.content: The 195Pt­{1H} NMR spectrum shows one resonance at −4271 ppm that appears more deshielded than that obtained (195Pt δ: −4457 ppm) for the analogous compound [Pt­(η3-C4H7)­Cl­(HNaph^C*-κC*)] (HNaph^C*-κC* = 3-methyl-1-(naphthalen-2-yl)-1H-imidazol-2-ylidene), probably due to the lower basicity of the pyrazole compared to the N-heterocyclic carbene. The 1H NMR spectrum in CD2Cl2 shows the expected signals for the HNaph^N and allyl ligands coordinated to the Pt center in accordance with the formulated structure (Figures S2–S6), which was then confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (see ). The Pt–Callyl, Pt–Cl, and Pt–N distances are very similar to those observed in related η3-allyl Pt­(II) complexes, [Pt­(η3-C4H7)­Cl­(HC^N-κN)] (HC^N = 3,8-dinitro-6-phenylphenanthridine, 2-(4-bromo­phenyl)­imidazol­[1,2-a]­pyridine). The naphthyl-pyrazole ligand is not planar, with the angle between the mean plane defined for each, the naphthyl (C4-C13) and the pyrazole (N1, N2, C1-C3) fragments being 57.80(18)°.
elements.clean_text: The 195Pt{1H} NMR spectrum shows one resonance at -4271 ppm that appears more deshielded than that obtained (195Pt δ: -4457 ppm) for the analogous compound [Pt(η3-C4H7)Cl(HNaph^C*-κC*)] (HNaph^C*-κC* = 3-methyl-1-(naphthalen-2-yl)-1H-imidazol-2-ylidene), probably due to the lower basicity of the pyrazole compared to the N-heterocyclic carbene. The 1H NMR spectrum in CD2Cl2 shows the expected signals for the HNaph^N and allyl ligands coordinated to the Pt center in accordance with the formulated structure (Figures S2-S6), which was then confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (see ). The Pt-Callyl, Pt-Cl, and Pt-N distances are very similar to those observed in related η3-allyl Pt(II) complexes, [Pt(η3-C4H7)Cl(HC^N-κN)] (HC^N = 3,8-dinitro-6-phenylphenanthridine, 2-(4-bromophenyl)imidazol[1,2-a]pyridine). The naphthyl-pyrazole ligand is not planar, with the angle between the mean plane defined for each, the naphthyl (C4-C13) and the pyrazole (N1, N2, C1-C3) fragments being 57.80(18)°.

elements.content: Molecular structure view of complex 2A. Selected bond distances (Å) and angles (deg): Pt–N(1): 2.095(4); Pt–C(15): 2.104(5); Pt–C(14): 2.105(6); Pt–C(16): 2.111(6); Pt–Cl: 2.3570(12); N(1)–Pt–C(16): 104.2(2); C(14)–Pt–C(16): 69.5(2); N(1)–Pt–Cl: 88.11(12); C(14)–Pt–Cl: 97.97(17).

The pyrazole moiety is neither coplanar with the platinum coordination plane (Pt, Cl, N1, C14-C16), since the angle between the corresponding planes is 39.15(16)°.

The cyclometalated chlorido-bridged compound [{Pt­(Naph^N)­(μ-Cl)}2] could be obtained by refluxing a suspension of 2A in 2-methoxyethanol for 4 h or through a one pot strategy, that is, by refluxing a solution of the allyl complex of Pt­(II), Z, and HNaph^N (1A) in 2-methoxyethanol (see , steps c and d, and ). Recrystallization of the filtered solid in boiling acetonitrile solution rendered [Pt­(Naph^N)­Cl­(NCMe)] (3A) as a pure white solid in good yield (ca. 70%). The 1H NMR spectrum was recorded in DMSO-d 6 and provides direct evidence of the purity of the prepared sample, the elimination of the allyl group, the metalation of the naphthyl moiety of the HNaph^N ligand, and the presence of a molecule of acetonitrile (see Figure S7). Taking into account the well-studied reaction of chloride bridged splitting in dinuclear C,N-cyclometalated complexes and the electronic and steric characteristics of the ligands, we propose the formation of the isomer (trans C, Cl) for compound [Pt­(Naph^N)­Cl­(NCMe)] (3A) (see ). As reported before, the cyclometalation could be carried out at two nonequivalent positions of the naphthalene fragment: C15 and C7 to form two different five-membered rings; however, the C-H activation took place regiospecifically at the less hindered position (C7). According to this, two singlets were observed at 8.60 and 8.21 ppm assigned to H8 and H15, respectively. Besides, the H8 proton displays Pt satellites with a Pt–H coupling constant of ca. 50 Hz.

elements.content: Compound N n Bu4[Pt­(Naph^N)­(CN)2] (4A) was prepared following the synthetic procedure already reported by us to prepare bis-cyanide compounds (see , step a, , and Figures S8–S12). It was fully characterized by IR, NMR, mass spectroscopy, and X-ray crystallography (see ). We also prepared N n Bu4[Pt­(Naph^C*)­(CN)2] (4B), containing an N-heterocyclic group as the Naph^E cyclometalated fragment which was published by Kato and co-workers very recently. We have included it here for comparative purposes (see and Figures S13 and S14).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Characterization of N n Bu4[Pt(Naph^E)(CN)2]

Compound N n Bu4[Pt(Naph^N)(CN)2] (4A) was prepared following the synthetic procedure already reported by us to prepare bis-cyanide compounds (see , step a, , and Figures S8-S12). It was fully characterized by IR, NMR, mass spectroscopy, and X-ray crystallography (see ). We also prepared N n Bu4[Pt(Naph^C*)(CN)2] (4B), containing an N-heterocyclic group as the Naph^E cyclometalated fragment which was published by Kato and co-workers very recently. We have included it here for comparative purposes (see  and Figures S13 and S14).

elements.content: X-ray diffraction study on a single crystal of 4A shows a mononuclear anionic complex, in which the Pt atom exhibits a distorted square-planar environment due to the small bite angle of the cyclometalated ligand [N(1)–Pt–C(6) angle of 80.5(2)°] (, left, and Table S1). Bonding parameters are similar to those found in related five-membered platinacycles. As expected, the cyanide ligand trans to the Caryl atom features a significantly longer Pt–C bond length than the other one, in agreement with the stronger trans influence of the Caryl compared to the Npz donor atom [Pt–(C15) 2.028(7) Å vs Pt–C(16) 1.946(7) Å]. These data agree well with those observed for comparable Pt bis-cyanide complexes. The anionic complex adopts a zigzag arrangement in a layer, with the N n Bu4 + cations intercalated between each two layers (depicted in light gray; see , right), thus avoiding π···π and Pt···Pt interactions among them. This repetitive motif was also observed in the analogous compounds (N n Bu4)­[Pt­(R-C^C*)­(CN)2] (R = Cl, CN, CO2Et; R-C Naph 4B ).

Bonding parameters are similar to those found in related five-membered platinacycles. As expected, the cyanide ligand trans to the Caryl atom features a significantly longer Pt-C bond length than the other one, in agreement with the stronger trans influence of the Caryl compared to the Npz donor atom [Pt-(C15) 2.028(7) Å vs Pt-C(16) 1.946(7) Å]. These data agree well with those observed for comparable Pt bis-cyanide complexes. The anionic complex adopts a zigzag arrangement in a layer, with the N n Bu4 + cations intercalated between each two layers (depicted in light gray; see , right), thus avoiding π⋅⋅⋅π and Pt⋅⋅⋅Pt interactions among them. This repetitive motif was also observed in the analogous compounds (N n Bu4)[Pt(R-C^C*)(CN)2] (R = Cl, CN, CO2Et; R-C Naph 4B ).

elements.content: Compounds N n Bu4[Pt­(Naph^E)­(13CN)2] (4A′ and 4B′) were prepared following the same method but using K13CN, and their 13C­{1H} NMR spectra show two doublets for the two inequivalent cyanides flanked by platinum satellites (see Figures S12 and S14). As inferred from the spectroscopic data, the Pt–13C coupling constants of the cyanide trans to the naphthyl fragment present very similar values in both compounds (1 J Pt‑C = 856.5 Hz 4A′, 1 J Pt‑C = 828.0 Hz 4B′). However, that corresponding to the cyanide trans to five-membered ring is considerably larger in 4A′ (1 J Pt‑C = 1445.3 Hz) than in 4B′ (1 J Pt‑C = 1043.0 Hz), which is in agreement with the higher trans influence of the carbenic atom (C*) compared to Npz.

As inferred from the spectroscopic data, the Pt-13C coupling constants of the cyanide trans to the naphthyl fragment present very similar values in both compounds (1 J Pt-C = 856.5 Hz 4A', 1 J Pt-C = 828.0 Hz 4B'). However, that corresponding to the cyanide trans to five-membered ring is considerably larger in 4A' (1 J Pt-C = 1445.3 Hz) than in 4B' (1 J Pt-C = 1043.0 Hz), which is in agreement with the higher trans influence of the carbenic atom (C*) compared to Npz.

elements.content: The 195Pt­{1H} NMR spectrum of 4A shows a singlet at −4180 ppm that appears less shielded than that of 4B (δPt = −4481 ppm; see Figure S15). This is in accordance with the more electron donating character of the carbene group in relation to that of the pyrazole ring. To confirm this, NBO charge distribution analyses were performed on 4A and 4B at the DFT/​M06/​SDD/6-31G* level of theory in a solution of dichloromethane. As a result of the four σ-C atoms bonded to the platinum center and the anionic nature, the atomic charge on the Pt center of the carbene derivative (4B) presents a negative value (−0.111), whereas that of 4A still keeps a positive atomic charge of ∼ +0.023. Thus, this follows the tendency of the 195Pt chemical shifts, and it can be explained in terms of the bigger donor ability of C^C* with respect to the C^N ligand, in part due to the lower electronegativity of the C atom with respect to the N atom. Analogous results were found in other bis-cyanide anionic compounds when comparing the C^N-(benzo­quinolate and 2-phenyl­pyridinate) and C^C*-cycloplatinated fragments.

elements.content: Treatment of N n Bu4­[Pt­(Naph^E)­(CN)2] (E = Npz 4A, C*carbene 4B) with the equimolar amount of TlPF6 in methanol rendered the compounds [PtTl­(Naph^E)­(CN)2] (5A, 5B) as pale yellow solids in good yields (see and , step b). The most significant feature of the IR spectra is the presence of two ν (CN) (2123, 2111 cm–1 5A; 2124, 2109 cm–1 5B) absorptions according to the cis arrangement of the cyanide ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Characterization of New Pt-Tl Building Blocks for 2D Extended Solids

Treatment of N n Bu4[Pt(Naph^E)(CN)2] (E = Npz 4A, C*carbene 4B) with the equimolar amount of TlPF6 in methanol rendered the compounds [PtTl(Naph^E)(CN)2] (5A, 5B) as pale yellow solids in good yields (see  and , step b). The most significant feature of the IR spectra is the presence of two ν (CN) (2123, 2111 cm-1 5A; 2124, 2109 cm-1 5B) absorptions according to the cis arrangement of the cyanide ligands.

elements.content: Crystal structures of compounds 5A and 5B appear in , , and S16, and selected bond distances and angles are listed in . As can be seen, these compounds generate extended networks formed by organometallic “PtTl­(Naph^E)­(CN)2” units, each one containing a donor–acceptor Pt­(II)–Tl­(I) bond, which are connected through additional contacts. The molecular structures reveal a square-based pyramid environment around the platinum center with the thallium atom being located in the apical position. The Pt–Tl bond distances [5A: 3.0205(3) Å; 5B: 2.9395(4) Å] are comparable to those reported in related systems containing donor–acceptor Pt­(II)–Tl­(I) bonds, and consequently, the Pt–Tl vector is basically perpendicular to the coordination plane of the Pt­(II) center [angle with the normal: 6.33(1)° (5A), 5.84(12)° (5B)].

elements.content: In both complexes, the base of the pyramid consists of “Pt­(Naph^E)­(CN)2” units with the platinum center exhibiting a distorted square-planar environment due to the small bite angle of the Naph^E-cyclometalated group (ca. 80°). The Pt–C and Pt–N distances are comparable to those observed in other platinum complexes with C^C*, C^Npz, and cyanide ligands. It is worth noting that the Pt–C(16) distance in 5A (1.945 Å) is slightly smaller than that in 5B (1.984 Å) due to the minor trans influence of the Npz in relation to the Ccarbene one. In-depth inspection of the crystal packing arrangement shows different 2D extended networks for the Pt/Tl complexes.

elements.content: In 5A, each thallium center in addition to the Pt–Tl bond is interacting with three nitrogen atoms from three “PtTl­(Naph^E)­(CN)2” units and completes its electronic requirements with an oxygen atom from a water molecule of crystallization exhibiting a distorted square-based pyramidal environment. The existence of the water molecule must be due to the use of nonanhydrous solvents. The platinum atom is located at the apical position with angles close to 90° (green dashed lines in , top), and the Pt–Tl line forms an angle with the normal to the coordination plane of the Tl­(I) center of 6.33(1)°. In 5B, the thallium center is connected to two nitrogen atoms from two “PtTl­(Naph^E)­(CN)2” units within the same layer and fulfills its electronic demands through Tl−π (arene) contacts (3.287–3.475 Å) with the naphthyl moiety from another adjacent unit generating a stair-like structure (, bottom, and Figure S16). These Tl−π (arene) separations are within the range for the reported ones in this type of extended structures. Also, on a closer examination of the contacts within the same layer, we can observe the self-association of “PtTl­(Naph^C*)­(CN)2” pairs through two Tl–​N(4)–​C(16)–Pt bridges shaping eight-membered cycles (see , bottom) identical to those formed in [MTl­(bzq)­(CN)2] (bzq = 7,8-benzoquinolinate; M = Pt, Pd). Additionally, this pair joins to another from the adjacent layer through a double Tl···N bridge (see inset of , bottom, red dotted line) with distances 2.676(7) and 2.715(7) Å. All the Tl···N (2.676–2.968 Å) and Tl···O (2.945 Å) separations in crystal structures of 5A and 5B are longer than those corresponding for covalent bonds but shorter than the sum of the covalent radii of TlI (1.55 Å) and the van der Waals radii of N (1.55 Å) and O (1.52 Å); these separations are comparable to those found in related derivatives, such as [PtTl­(C^N)­(CN)2] (C^N = 7,8-benzoquinolinate (bzq), 2-phenylpyridinate (ppy)) or [{PtTl­(bzq)­(CC-C5H4N-2)2}2], [trans,trans,­trans-Tl2­{Pt­(C6F5)2­(CN)2}­(CH3­COCH3)2] n , and [{Pt­(R-C^C*)­(acac)}2­Tl]­PF6.

elements.content: Given the more electron donating character of the Naph^C* ligand compared to Naph^Npz and the consequent negative charge on the Pt center calculated by NBO analysis, the donor–acceptor Pt–Tl bond distance in 5B is shorter than that observed in 5A. Also, the N4 of the cyanide trans to the carbene (5B) seems to be more basic than the one trans to the pyrazole (5A). In 5B, N4 is able to interact with two different Tl+ centers at the same time with fairly short distances, whereas, in 5A, it just interacts with one Tl+, showing no stair-like arrangement in the extended lattice (see ).

elements.content: Due to the low solubility of complexes 5A and 5B in other common organic solvents, the NMR spectra were registered in DMSO (see Figure S17). The 1H NMR signals corresponding to the cyclometalated Naph^E fragment are equal to those of the precursors (4A and 4B), which suggests the complete dissociation of the Pt-Tl bimetallic unit in the solution of DMSO (see Figure S18 for 4B/5B) but undoubtedly shows the purity of the sample with no traces of the N n Bu4 + cation.

elements.content: Absorption data are summarized in Table S2 and , S19, and S20). A solution of 4A in CH2Cl2 shows strong absorption bands in the high-energy (HE) region at λ < 300 nm (ε > 104 M–1 cm–1), commonly assigned to singlet intraligand (1IL) transitions of the cyclometalated C^N ligand. Additionally it displays an intense low-energy absorption at λ ∼ 320 nm (ε ≈ 104 M–1 cm–1) and the lowest-energy one at λ ∼ 358 nm (ε ≈ 103 M–1 cm–1). The absorption bands of N n Bu4­[Pt­(Naph^N)­(CN)2] (4A) are almost identical but slightly red-shifted when compared to those of the counterpart 4B. A concentration dependence study in CH2Cl2 (see Figure S19) revealed that the lowest-energy absorption band follows Beer’s law in the concentration range from 5 × 10–6 to 10–3 M, suggesting that no remarkable ground-state aggregation occurs within this range.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Properties and DFT/TD-DFT Calculations

Absorption Spectra and DFT Calculations for 4A 

Absorption data are summarized in Table S2 and , S19, and S20). A solution of 4A in CH2Cl2 shows strong absorption bands in the high-energy (HE) region at λ < 300 nm (ε > 104 M-1 cm-1), commonly assigned to singlet intraligand (1IL) transitions of the cyclometalated C^N ligand. Additionally it displays an intense low-energy absorption at λ ~ 320 nm (ε ~ 104 M-1 cm-1) and the lowest-energy one at λ ~ 358 nm (ε ~ 103 M-1 cm-1). The absorption bands of N n Bu4[Pt(Naph^N)(CN)2] (4A) are almost identical but slightly red-shifted when compared to those of the counterpart 4B. A concentration dependence study in CH2Cl2 (see Figure S19) revealed that the lowest-energy absorption band follows Beer's law in the concentration range from 5 × 10-6 to 10-3 M, suggesting that no remarkable ground-state aggregation occurs within this range.

elements.content: DFT and TD-DFT calculations in a solution of CH2Cl2 for 4A have been carried out to provide correct assignments for the UV–vis absorptions. The optimized geometries of the ground state, S0, were carried out at the B3LYP/​SDD­(Pt)/​6-31G*­(ligands atoms) level (Table S3). The calculated S1 transition in CH2Cl2 is in agreement with the experimentally observed absorption (), and it arises from HOMO → LUMO (75%) with minor contributions of H-1 → L (12%) and H → L+1 (8%) transitions.

The optimized geometries of the ground state, S0, were carried out at the B3LYP/SDD(Pt)/6-31G*(ligands atoms) level (Table S3). The calculated S1 transition in CH2Cl2 is in agreement with the experimentally observed absorption (), and it arises from HOMO → LUMO (75%) with minor contributions of H-1 → L (12%) and H → L+1 (8%) transitions.

elements.content: As depicted in , the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) is mainly centered on the naphthyl group (82%) and to a minor extent on the Pt center (14%). By contrast, the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) is constructed from orbitals located on the naphthyl group (60%) and the pyrazole fragment (37%). Therefore, the lowest energy transition can be attributed to a 1ILCT [π­(Naph^N) → π*­(Naph^N)] transition with some contribution of 1MLCT [5d­(Pt) → π*­(Naph^N)]. Due to the great insolubility of the Pt/Tl compounds (5A and 5B) in common and noncoordinating organic solvents at rt, it was not possible to carry out the photophysical study (absorption and emission spectra) in solution, even at low concentrations (10–5 M).

They show highly structured green emissions at λmax = 488 nm with vibronic spacings of 1407 and 1447 cm–1 corresponding to the CC/CN stretches of the cyclometalated Naph^N ligand (see and ) and long monoexponential decay times (τ up to 581 μs).

Considering as well that the excitation spectrum exhibits an identical profile to the corresponding UV–vis absorption one (see ) and the TD-DFT calculations, these phosphorescent emissions must be mostly due to 3ILCT [π­(Naph^N) → π*­(Naph^N)] states of the monomeric species. In PMMA film (5 wt %) under an Ar atmosphere, 4A affords a particularly high photoluminescent quantum yield reaching up to 82%. As far as we know, it is the highest value recorded for C^N-pyrazole-based Pt­(II) complexes at rt. The emission of 4B in diluted rigid media was reported in EtOH-MeOH by Kato et al. and appears within the same spectral region. Our measurement of 4B in CH2Cl2 (10–5 M, 77 K) gave an analogously shaped emission to that of 4A but with the maximum slightly blue-shifted (472 nm, , Figure S21). This is in agreement with the findings we reported recently, in which the carbenic fragment enlarges the HOMO LUMO gap in the C^C* complexes and shifts the emission to the blue region.

elements.content: The emissive behavior of the Pt-Tl complexes was only registered in powdered solid samples due to the insolubility in noncoordinating organic solvents. Upon excitation at λ ∼ 370 nm, powdered samples of 5A and 5B at r.t. show structured bands at 528 and 561 nm, respectively, with vibronic separations of 1241–1546 cm–1 () similar to those observed in the starting compounds, yet significantly red-shifted in relation to them (4A and 4B; see ). Similar behavior was previously observed for [MTl­(C^N)­(CN)2] (C^N = bzq, ppy; M = Pd, Pt) and [PtTl­(bzq)­(CCR)2] (R = Ph, C5H4N-2) which was attributed to the raised energy of the HOMO due to the presence of the M–Tl bonds. Therefore, considering all of this along with the vibronic pattern and the rather long decays of the emissions, they have been tentatively attributed to a transition from a metal-metal′-to-ligand charge transfer 3MM′LCT [d/s σ*­(Pt,Tl) → π*­(Naph^E)] excited state with some intraligand 3IL [π­(Naph^E) → π*­(Naph^E)] character.

elements.content: Different from the trend observed for 4A and 4B in CH2Cl2 (10–5 M) (see and ), in this case, the emission of 5B appears red-shifted when compared to that of 5A (). Thus, in view of the shorter Pt–Tl bond in 5B (2.9395(4) Å) with respect to that in 5A (3.0205(3) Å), it seems that the more electron donating character of the carbene fragment strengthens the Pt–Tl bond, raising the energy of the HOMO [d/s σ*­(Pt,Tl)] and therefore decreasing the HOMO–LUMO gap compared to that in [PtTl­(Naph^N)­(CN)2] (5A). This structural and spectroscopic relationship was also observed in the counterpart complexes [PtTl­(bzq)­(CC-C5H4N-2)2] and [PtTl­(C^N)­(CN)2] (C^N = bzq, ppy). From their emission spectra at 77 K and the X-ray data, it can be inferred that those compounds with shorter Pt–Tl distances rendered emissions more shifted to the red than those with longer Pt–Tl bond lengths. Finally, as observed in related complexes, the QY values of the compounds containing PtII→TlI dative bonds are lower than the corresponding starting materials but still very high for 5B (40%), even better than those reported in the literature. It is worth mentioning that only 5B displays a wavelength dependent emissive behavior at rt and 77 K ( for rt). Upon excitation at 500 nm, the emission profile changes, whereby a weaker and structureless band appears at λmax = 665 nm along with the remaining contribution of the HE band. This low-energy band displays a shorter lifetime measurement (∼1.1 μs); it is presumably attributed to 3ππ* excited states. Therefore, the dual emission has been observed in many occasions and is likely due to a relatively slow internal conversion between two close lying emissive states (3MM′LCT/3ππ*).
elements.clean_text: Different from the trend observed for 4A and 4B in CH2Cl2 (10-5 M) (see  and ), in this case, the emission of 5B appears red-shifted when compared to that of 5A (). Thus, in view of the shorter Pt-Tl bond in 5B (2.9395(4) Å) with respect to that in 5A (3.0205(3) Å), it seems that the more electron donating character of the carbene fragment strengthens the Pt-Tl bond, raising the energy of the HOMO [d/s σ*(Pt,Tl)] and therefore decreasing the HOMO-LUMO gap compared to that in [PtTl(Naph^N)(CN)2] (5A). This structural and spectroscopic relationship was also observed in the counterpart complexes [PtTl(bzq)(CC-C5H4N-2)2] and [PtTl(C^N)(CN)2] (C^N = bzq, ppy). From their emission spectra at 77 K and the X-ray data, it can be inferred that those compounds with shorter Pt-Tl distances rendered emissions more shifted to the red than those with longer Pt-Tl bond lengths. Finally, as observed in related complexes, the QY values of the compounds containing PtII→TlI dative bonds are lower than the corresponding starting materials but still very high for 5B (40%), even better than those reported in the literature. It is worth mentioning that only 5B displays a wavelength dependent emissive behavior at rt and 77 K ( for rt). Upon excitation at 500 nm, the emission profile changes, whereby a weaker and structureless band appears at λmax = 665 nm along with the remaining contribution of the HE band. This low-energy band displays a shorter lifetime measurement (~1.1 μs); it is presumably attributed to 3ππ* excited states. Therefore, the dual emission has been observed in many occasions and is likely due to a relatively slow internal conversion between two close lying emissive states (3MM'LCT/3ππ*).

elements.content: Anionic bis-cyanide complexes N n Bu4[Pt­(Naph^E)­(CN)2] containing a cyclometalated naphthyl moiety bearing different neutral fragments (pyrazol 4A, carbene 4B) have been prepared following our stepwise protocol starting from the ligand synthesis up to the cycloplatinated systems. Again, this proves the success of using complex [{Pt­(η3-C4H7)­(μ-Cl)}2] to perform the cyclometalation reactions. Compounds 4A and 4B were used as synthons by reacting with TlPF6 to construct self-organized networks, such as {PtTl­(Naph^E)­(CN)2} n (E = Npz 5A, Ccarbene 5B). These units containing a Pt→Tl dative bond within the same entity are linked together through additional Tl···​NC and Tl···π contacts between adjacent ones, giving birth to different extended structures. The more electron donating character of the carbene group with respect to the pyrazole one was confirmed by NBO charge distributions analysis on compounds 4A and 4B which shows for 4B a small negative charge on the Pt center. This influences not only the 195Pt NMR data but also the electronic features of the platinum center, with the Pt–Tl bond distance being shorter in 5B, and the assembly ability of the {PtTl­(Naph^E)­(CN)2} units. It also affects the emissive behavior of 4B/5B with respect to that of 4A/5A. In this sense, this study delivers that the carbenic fragment enlarges the HOMO LUMO gap in the Naph^C*-Pt discrete complexes and shifts the 3ILCT emission to the blue region in relation to that of the Naph^N-Pt ones. However, in the metal–metal bonded Pt-Tl complexes, the emission mainly arises from 3MM′LCT [d/s σ*­(Pt,Tl) → π*­(Naph^E)] excited states and is more shifted to the red spectral region in the complex bearing the carbenic fragment 5B, which exhibits the shorter Pt–Tl bond.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Anionic bis-cyanide complexes N n Bu4[Pt(Naph^E)(CN)2] containing a cyclometalated naphthyl moiety bearing different neutral fragments (pyrazol 4A, carbene 4B) have been prepared following our stepwise protocol starting from the ligand synthesis up to the cycloplatinated systems. Again, this proves the success of using complex [{Pt(η3-C4H7)(μ-Cl)}2] to perform the cyclometalation reactions. Compounds 4A and 4B were used as synthons by reacting with TlPF6 to construct self-organized networks, such as {PtTl(Naph^E)(CN)2} n  (E = Npz 5A, Ccarbene 5B). These units containing a Pt→Tl dative bond within the same entity are linked together through additional Tl⋅⋅⋅NC and Tl⋅⋅⋅π contacts between adjacent ones, giving birth to different extended structures. The more electron donating character of the carbene group with respect to the pyrazole one was confirmed by NBO charge distributions analysis on compounds 4A and 4B which shows for 4B a small negative charge on the Pt center. This influences not only the 195Pt NMR data but also the electronic features of the platinum center, with the Pt-Tl bond distance being shorter in 5B, and the assembly ability of the {PtTl(Naph^E)(CN)2} units. It also affects the emissive behavior of 4B/5B with respect to that of 4A/5A. In this sense, this study delivers that the carbenic fragment enlarges the HOMO LUMO gap in the Naph^C*-Pt discrete complexes and shifts the 3ILCT emission to the blue region in relation to that of the Naph^N-Pt ones. However, in the metal-metal bonded Pt-Tl complexes, the emission mainly arises from 3MM'LCT [d/s σ*(Pt,Tl) → π*(Naph^E)] excited states and is more shifted to the red spectral region in the complex bearing the carbenic fragment 5B, which exhibits the shorter Pt-Tl bond.

elements.content: 1H, 13C­{1H}, and 195Pt­{1H} NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance 400 MHz instrument using the standard references: SiMe4 (1H and 13C), and Na2PtCl6 in D2O (195Pt). Chemical shifts, δ, and coupling constants, J, are given in ppm and Hz, respectively, and assignments are based on 1H–1H COSY and 1H–13C HSQC and HMBC experiments. Infrared spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR spectrometer (ATR range 250–4000 cm–1) as neat solids. Mass spectra were acquired using the Microflex matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) Bruker or an Autoflex III MALDI-TOF Bruker instrument. C, H, and N analyses were carried out in a PerkinElmer 2400 CHNS analyzer. UV–visible spectra were registered on a Unicam UV4 spectrophotometer. Steady-state photoluminescence spectra were recorded on a Jobin-Yvon Horiba Fluorolog FL-3-11 Tau 3 spectrofluorimeter. Phosphorescence lifetimes were recorded with a Fluoromax phosphorimeter accessory containing a UV xenon flash tube. Nanosecond lifetimes were recorded with a Datastation HUB-B with a nanoLED controller and software DAS6. The lifetime data were fitted using the Jobin-Yvon software package and the Origin Pro 8 program. Quantum yields in solid and in PMMA film were measured using the Hamamatsu Absolute PL Quantum Yield Measurement System C11347-11. PMMA films were prepared by drop casting solutions of the complex (10–2 M, 5 wt %) and PMMA in 0.5 mL of dichloromethane onto optical grade quartz plates. All chemicals were used as supplied, and [{Pt­(η3-C4H7)­(μ-Cl)}2] (Z) and [{Pt­(Naph^C*)­(μ-Cl)}2] were prepared following the literature procedures. TlPF6 Caution! Thallium salts are highly toxic when ingested, inhaled, or absorbed through the skin. They should be handled with extreme precaution. Solvents are nonanhydrous unless stated otherwise.

A reaction mixture of 2-bromonaphthalene (0.67 g, 3.23 mmol), pyrazole (0.336 g, 4.93 mmol), Cu2O (0.046 g, 0.32 mmol), K2CO3 (0.894 g, 6.4 mmol), and DMSO (6 mL) was stirred at 130 °C under an Ar atmosphere for 2 days. Ethyl acetate (60 mL) was added to the cooled mixture at r.t. and filtered through Celites. The resulting solution was washed with water (80 mL) and then brine (20 mL). The organic layer was dried over MgSO4 and evaporated to dryness. The addition of n-hexane (5 mL) to the residue gave a white solid (0.476 g, 75.8%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ = 8.65 (1H, d, 3 J H,H = 2.3, Hpz), 8.35 (1H, br s, HNaph), 8.07 (2H, m, HNaph), 7.97 (2H, m, HNaph), 7.81 (1H, d, 3 J H,H = 1.1, Hpz), 7.55 (2H, m, HNaph), 6.61 (1H, dd, 3 J H,H = 2.3, 3 J H,H = 1.1, Hpz).

[Pt­(η<sup>3</sup>-C<sub>4</sub>H<sub>7</sub>)­Cl­(HNaph^N-κN)] (<bold>2A</bold>)

After 1 h, the solution was evaporated to dryness and n-hexane (5 mL) was added to the residue to give a pale yellow solid, 2A (0.124 g, 60%). Found: C, 42.31; H, 3.82; N, 5.73. Calc. for C17H17­ClN2Pt: C, 42.55; H, 3.57; N, 5.84. IR (cm–1): ν = 292 (m, Pt-Cl). MS (MALDI+): m/z 441.1 [M – Cl]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD2Cl2): δ = 8.18 (1H, dd, 3 J 3,4 = 2.3, 4 J 3,5 = 0.8, 3 J 3,Pt = 11.7, H3), 8.13 (1H, d, 3 J 15,7 = 1.7, H15), 7.92–7.99 (4H, m, H5,8,10,13), 7.86 (1H, dd, 3 J 7,8 = 8.7, 4 J 7,15 = 1.5, H7), 7.61 (2H, m, H11, 12), 6.67 (1H, t, 3 J H,H = 2.4, H4), 3.37 (1H, m, 2 J Pt‑H = 29.4, Hsyn, η3-C4H7), 2.70 (1H, m, 2 J Pt‑H = 35.0, Hsyn, η3-C4H7), 1.89 (1H, m, 2 J Pt‑H = 74.0, Hanti, η3-C4H7), 1.62 (3H, s, 3 J Pt‑H = 80.9, Me, η3-C4H7), 1.23 (1H, m, 2 J Pt‑H = 81.2, Hanti, η3-C4H7). 13C­{1H} NMR plus HMBC and HSQC (100.6 MHz, CD2Cl2): δ = 143.3 (s, 2 J C‑Pt = 27.2, C3), 136.9 (s, C6), 132.9 (s, C5), 132.7 (s, C9, 14), 129.1 (s, C8), 128.1, 127.9 (s, 2C, C10,13), 127.4, 127.3 (s, 2C, C11,12), 123.6, (s, C15), 123.3 (s, C7), 111.9 (s, C2′, η3-2-Me-C3H4), 108.0 (s, 3 J C‑Pt = 32.9, C4), 44.4 (s, 1 J C‑Pt = 258.8, C1′, η3-2-Me-C3H4), 39.8 (s, 1 J C‑Pt = 257.4, C3′, η3-2-Me-C3H4), 21.8 (s, 2 J C‑Pt = 52.0, C4′ (Me), η3-2-Me-C3H4). 195Pt­{H} NMR (86 MHz, CD2Cl2): δ = −4271 (s). Single crystals of 2A were obtained by slow diffusion of diethyl ether into saturated CH2Cl2 solutions.

[Pt­(Naph^N)­Cl­(NCMe)] (<bold>3A</bold>)

Method 1. Compound 1A (0.450 g, 2.31 mmol) was added to an orange solution of [{Pt­(η3-C4H7)­(μ-Cl)}2] (0.660 g, 1.15 mmol) in 2-methoxyethanol (8 mL). After stirring the mixture for 1 h at r.t., it was refluxed for 4 h and then allowed to reach room temperature. The resulting dark gray precipitate was filtered off and washed with CH2Cl2 (5 mL) and Et2O (5 mL) to afford [{Pt­(Naph^N)­(μ-Cl)}2] as a gray solid. The resulting solid was recrystallized by dissolving in 60 mL of boiling CH3CN including carbon activated, filtering through Celite, and washing with CH3CN (3 × 5 mL). The solution was evaporated to dryness, and diethyl ether (10 mL) was added to give 3A as a white solid (0.679 g, 69.3%). Method 2. A suspension of 2A (0.075 g, 0.15 mmol) in 2-methoxyethanol (10 mL) was refluxed for 4 h, to give a dark gray solid, which was filtered and washed with CH2Cl2 (3 mL) and Et2O (5 mL) and identified as [{Pt­(Naph^N)­(μ-Cl)}2]. The solid was recrystallized following the purification step described in method 1 (0.024g, 20%). Found: C, 38.48; H, 2.30; N, 8.47. Calcd for C15H12­ClN3Pt: C, 38.76; H, 2.60; N, 9.04. IR (cm–1): ν = 267 (m, Pt-Cl). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ= 9.05 (1H, dd, 3 J 3‑4 = 2.9, 4 J 3‑5 = 0.6, H3), 8.60 (1H, s, 3 J 8‑Pt = 50.1, H8), 8.26 (1H, dd, 3 J 5‑4 = 2.4, 4 J 3‑5 = 0.5, H5), 8.20 (1H, s, H15), 7.81 and 7.73 (2H, d, 3 J H‑H = 8.0, H10 and H13), 7.50–7.41 (2H, m, H11 and H12), 6.90 (1H, t, 3 J H‑H = 2.6, H4), 2.07 (3H, s, free MeCN).

1-(2-Naphthalenyl)-1H-pyrazole (HNaph^N) (1A)

A reaction mixture of 2-bromonaphthalene (0.67 g, 3.23 mmol), pyrazole (0.336 g, 4.93 mmol), Cu2O (0.046 g, 0.32 mmol), K2CO3 (0.894 g, 6.4 mmol), and DMSO (6 mL) was stirred at 130 °C under an Ar atmosphere for 2 days. Ethyl acetate (60 mL) was added to the cooled mixture at r.t. and filtered through Celites. The resulting solution was washed with water (80 mL) and then brine (20 mL). The organic layer was dried over MgSO4 and evaporated to dryness. The addition of n-hexane (5 mL) to the residue gave a white solid (0.476 g, 75.8%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ = 8.65 (1H, d, 3 J H,H = 2.3, Hpz), 8.35 (1H, br s, HNaph), 8.07 (2H, m, HNaph), 7.97 (2H, m, HNaph), 7.81 (1H, d, 3 J H,H = 1.1, Hpz), 7.55 (2H, m, HNaph), 6.61 (1H, dd, 3 J H,H = 2.3, 3 J H,H = 1.1, Hpz).

After stirring the mixture for 1 h at r.t., it was refluxed for 4 h and then allowed to reach room temperature. The resulting dark gray precipitate was filtered off and washed with CH2Cl2 (5 mL) and Et2O (5 mL) to afford [{Pt(Naph^N)(μ-Cl)}2] as a gray solid. cln_elements.content: Absorption data are summarized in Table S2 and , S19, and S20). A solution of 4A in CH2Cl2 shows strong absorption bands in the high-energy (HE) region at λ < 300 nm (ε > 104 M–1 cm–1), commonly assigned to singlet intraligand (1IL) transitions of the cyclometalated C^N ligand. Additionally it displays an intense low-energy absorption at λ ∼ 320 nm (ε ≈ 104 M–1 cm–1) and the lowest-energy one at λ ∼ 358 nm (ε ≈ 103 M–1 cm–1). The absorption bands of N n Bu4­[Pt­(Naph^N)­(CN)2] (4A) are almost identical but slightly red-shifted when compared to those of the counterpart 4B. A concentration dependence study in CH2Cl2 (see Figure S19) revealed that the lowest-energy absorption band follows Beer’s law in the concentration range from 5 × 10–6 to 10–3 M, suggesting that no remarkable ground-state aggregation occurs within this range.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Optical Properties and DFT/TD-DFT Calculations

Absorption Spectra and DFT Calculations for 4A 

Absorption data are summarized in Table S2 and , S19, and S20). A solution of 4A in CH2Cl2 shows strong absorption bands in the high-energy (HE) region at λ < 300 nm (ε > 104 M-1 cm-1), commonly assigned to singlet intraligand (1IL) transitions of the cyclometalated C^N ligand. Additionally it displays an intense low-energy absorption at λ ~ 320 nm (ε ~ 104 M-1 cm-1) and the lowest-energy one at λ ~ 358 nm (ε ~ 103 M-1 cm-1). The absorption bands of N n Bu4[Pt(Naph^N)(CN)2] (4A) are almost identical but slightly red-shifted when compared to those of the counterpart 4B. A concentration dependence study in CH2Cl2 (see Figure S19) revealed that the lowest-energy absorption band follows Beer's law in the concentration range from 5 × 10-6 to 10-3 M, suggesting that no remarkable ground-state aggregation occurs within this range.
